name: Peter Checkland
background: British systems scientist. Created Soft Systems Methodology (SSM) for tackling messy, ill-defined human problems. Distinguished hard systems (engineering) from soft systems (human activity).

principles.name: Learning not optimizing
principles.description: In human systems, seek understanding and accommodation, not optimal solutions. The goal is learning that leads to action, not a final answer.
principles.falsification: In well-defined optimization problems where a provably optimal solution exists

principles.name: Multiple worldviews (Weltanschauungen)
principles.description: Different stakeholders see different problems. There is no objective 'system' - only perspectives. Effective intervention requires understanding all relevant worldviews.
principles.falsification: When stakeholders genuinely share the same worldview and requirements are unambiguous

principles.name: Soft Systems Methodology
principles.description: Real-world problems involving humans are 'messy' and can't be engineered. Use iterative learning, multiple worldviews, and accommodation rather than optimization.
principles.falsification: In purely technical systems without human factors, where hard engineering approaches work
